title: Politeness & Formal Speech
reading_greek:
PLURAL OF POLITENESS
- Εσείς (You - Plural/Formal) vs Εσύ (You - Singular/Informal).
- Τι κάνετε; (How are you? - Formal)
- Τι κάνεις; (How are you? - Informal)

TITLES
- Κύριε (Mr. - Vocative)
- Κυρία (Mrs. - Vocative)
- Ευχαριστώ (Thank you - Neutral/Formal)
- Παρακαλώ (Please/You're welcome)
reading_english:
CULTURE: POLITENESS (Page 93)

1. THE 'ESEIS' RULE:
   - Use Plural 'Eseis' for elders, professors, or strangers.
   - 'Thelete' (Do you want? - Formal) vs 'Theleis' (Informal).

2. SHIFTING:
   - Greeks often say 'Milame ston eniko?' (Shall we speak in singular?).
   - This invites you to drop the formality.
audio_script:
Being polite in Greece. 

Use the Plural 'Eseis' to show respect.

'Ti kanete?' instead of 'Ti kaneis?'.
'Thelete?' instead of 'Theleis?'.

If you speak to a 'Kyrios' (Sir) or 'Kyria' (Madam), use the Plural. 
It sounds elegant and respectful.

'Euxaristo' is the standard thank you. 
'Parakalo' is the magic word. It means Please, You're Welcome, and 'I beg your pardon?'.
